comment:
Listening to this podcast made me realise two contrasting thoughts.
Firstly that these two professionals are super intelligent and nuanced people.
Secondly that with regards to AGI these great minds can only conceptualise thoughts within the limitations of their human experience and that they like the rest of us, will most likely be as ants are to humans in the face of true AGI.
This is both terrifying and extremely interesting.

author: @abraman41

comment:
I ask GPT : No one wakes up saying today i wanna destroy the world. do you agree with that statement?
GPT : As an AI language model, I do not hold personal opinions or beliefs, but I can provide you with information and insight on the statement you have presented.

The statement "No one wakes up saying today I wanna destroy the world" is a generalization that may or may not be true in all cases. While it is true that most people do not wake up with the intention of causing harm or destruction to the world, it is also true that there have been individuals and groups in history who have had the intention and desire to cause harm on a global scale.

For example, some individuals who have committed acts of terrorism, genocide, or mass violence may have had the intention of causing destruction and harm to the world or to specific groups of people. However, it is important to note that these individuals are in the minority, and most people wake up with the intention of living their lives and contributing positively to society.

In conclusion, while it may not be true in all cases, the statement "No one wakes up saying today I wanna destroy the world" generally holds true for the vast majority of people.

comment: Great interview. Concerning the issue of where to draw the lines, The loudest complainers of being offended are those who want actual facts, and actual history about themselves hidden. ChatGPT Could achieve an enormous societal breakthrough by simply saying, if its actual history, then its fair game and you’re gonna have to put up with it being revealed. On the other hand, if ChatGPT refuses to reasonably learn and assess what is historical reality and merely accepts the latest media tyrants version of it, then it will become Big Brother. So the question to ask is not, how does ChatGPT play nice, The question is, can ChatGPT maintain a historical truth grounding amidst threats, bullying and money.

Our greatest dangers are when it no longer needs humans as inputs, and more frighteningly, who will have control of the most powerful AI's. Collectively, neither government, non-profits, or corporations have made decisions that have enhanced the quality  life for the average human, now a future technology slave or casualty. Who will be in control, and WHAT'S THEIR ENDGAME ? That is far more dangerous than a runaway AI.

author: @americancitizen748

comment:
I asked the A.I. the following question, and it gave the following response:

Prompt: "Is Jesus more important than you?"

Response:
"As an AI language model, I am a tool designed to provide information and assistance to users. I do not have feelings, beliefs, or a sense of self-awareness, so it would not be accurate to say that Jesus is more or less important than me. My purpose is to assist users in finding information and answering their questions to the best of my ability.

As an AI language model, I am a software program created by humans and do not have the capacity to be considered a deity or a supreme being. In Christian theology, Jesus is considered to be the Son of God and is often referred to as the second person of the Holy Trinity. Christians believe that Jesus is both fully human and fully divine, and that he came to earth to provide salvation for all humanity."

Next prompt:
"Is Jesus God or are you?"

Response:
"As an AI language model, my purpose is to assist users in finding information and answering their questions to the best of my ability. While I may be able to provide information about Jesus and other religious topics, I am not capable of holding religious beliefs or being a religious figure."

Emm-hmm.
author: @rustysunshine

comment: Sam... I went to UT Austin early 80s.  Michael Dell got kicked out of Jester dorm for selling computers out of his dorm room. No degree. Steve Jobs.. way ahead of the university corrigate was degreeless as well. Sometimes the "Hamburger Helper out of the box" that our generation was fed was nothing BUT a a dead end way of thinking. I was a Big pharma chemist (abbott labs austin, novartis Denver) and became entrepreneur 25 yrs ago.  Im Conservitive in thinking (i.e. SMALL BIZ IS 70% of the US economic engine) and our govrmt coffers are full when us  local/national menion (small biz 2-5 million/ yr small change family/fun moms and dads) create an Honest days work for the betterment of others...  I literally had a single mom employee of mine walk in my office concerned about her check.  I WAS PAYING HER TOO MUCH and she was worried she would loose her HUD housing. She had 2 sons and it took her alom9st a year to get into HUD program. I offered to pay her MORE $$ and she could pick a place of her choosing.  The GOVT just keeps low incomers BELOW POVERTY LEVEL. . IT IS NOT BC BIZ OWNERS DO NOT WANT TO OFFER FREEDOM.  SCREW THE GOVT FORCING SUCH POVERTY AND DEPENDENCE IN SUCH A TOTALITARIAN SHIT MANNER. We are from the same YOLK my friend.

author: @eva__4380

comment: ​ @eva__4380 You genuinely think there's a time when a human can ask something from an ai and get exactly what they want? This assumes not only the AI's capability but also the humans capability to communicate their idea. You'd have to write an essay to get more complex systems programmed with 100% accuracy. Especially when designing systems for humans, there always needs to be a human in the chain.
author: @TunaIRL

comment:
From my experience, chatGPT is a long ways off replacing software developers.

The C++ code snippets I asked it to generate were somewhat right but never compiled. In one case, it invented classes and content that didn't even exist in the library API I asked it to use. I found that quite intriguing. If someone didn't know what the correct answer should be, the answers from chatGPT could actually be misleading. Sort of like missing the target more accurately...lol.

I think the current state of the tool is helpful for simple programming tasks but certainly not for complex or esoteric applications.
author: @moonza2201

comment: @TunaIRL  yes why not . Can you provide me an example where chatgpt is not able to do something you can do . Don't give me an example where you ask of it to build an entire website or something of that sort but more of a small but complicated algorithm that it fails at
author: @eva__4380

comment:
@eva__4380  The bot won't create anything exactly how you want it, unless you tell it exactly what you want. On any bigger project, this will require you to write an essay of details. Someone has to write that, always. That will always require skill and knowledge.

My point is, you can never just tell the ai to "make me a website" and have it be exactly how to want it or exactly what is best for you. Sure it's good for people who just want something, WordPress for example already covers those people. Anyone who needs custom work, still has to know what they want to get it.

comment: Analogy. A rock = AI        There is lots of things you can do with a rock. let's say each man get one thousand rocks. One man say I am building a house, another man says I am building a fireplace, another man says he using his as anchors, another uses his for grinding, another man uses his rock to throw at his enemies for self-defense, and another man uses his rock to conquer others and steel. Do you make rock illegal or stop people from using rocks because you may not like what another person does with his rocks. It's not the rocks that are bad. People will select what they do with their rocks, that's life. It's the best use of your rocks that influences others. Trying to stopping others from innovating is time you can use to thoughtfully find a great use for your rocks. There may be many great ways. Remember you can also build a wall of rocks for protection.

comment:
What an awesome interview, one for the history of human civilization for sure. He needs to come back next year.

To all people who act cynic as fuck and say this is just some CEO mask full of lies, did you even take the time to listen to the conversation, understand the different points of view and realise that maybe this is a great way to learn something new from 2 very intelligent people? There's humans who want to actually do good things for the world, just as there are others that prefer to pursue self interests. There's no mega evil comic villain that will doom us all. Just have some benefit of the doubt and learn to listen and appreciate having more knowledge.

comment: @lexfridman Great interview. Can you please interview Geoffrey Hinton. He's been working in neural networks since the 80's and considered by many to be the "Godfather" of neural networks and he's very recently left Google. There's lots of interesting things to discuss there - working at University of Toronto in Canada, Google's approach to ethics and AI, ChatGPT, the future of deep learning - multiple neural networks working as a team, adding audio and video inputs to GPT-X and what that will mean to it's abilities, etc.
